Step-by-step Guide for Newcomers in BelgiumThis guide will help you understand what to do when you arrive in Belgium.
 Temporary Protection (TP) in Belgium: Quick Guide open

1 Where does registration take place?

All matters are handled at the single registration center IBZ in Brussels.

location_onAddress: Rue Belliard 68, 1040 Bruxelles.
scheduleTime: It is recommended to arrive before 08:00. There is a separate queue for Ukrainians.

2 What documents should you prepare?

The main goal is to prove that you were living in Ukraine as of 24.02.2022.

assignment_turned_inRequired: International and internal passports.
folder_openProof of residence: Bank statements, work/medical certificates, documents from 'Diia', court decisions.
starImportant: A certificate from the State Border Guard Service about crossing the border (can be ordered online) significantly simplifies the procedure.

3 Registration stages

fingerprint

Biometrics

Taking fingerprints and photographing.

chat

Interview

Communication with the inspector through an interpreter (you can choose Ukrainian or Russian).

hourglass_empty

Waiting

The decision can be given immediately (document with photo) or sent by mail within 30 days to the address you provided.

4 Housing and finances

account_balance_walletBudget: Have a reserve of funds for the first 2-3 months of living (food, transport), as the processing of social benefits may take time.
homeAddress: To receive Card A, a physical address is mandatory (with friends or in social housing) where the police can check you.

5 Result

description

Annex 15

Temporary document that you receive after approval. With it, you go to the local commune (city hall) at your future place of residence.

credit_card

Card A

Plastic residence permit that gives the right to work and access to the social system.

info

Please note

We recommend double-checking information as addresses and operating hours may change.

1
verified_user

Obtain Protection in Belgium

Go to the registration centre in Brussels at Rue Belliard 68, 1000 Brussels. The centre is open from Monday to Friday, with registration starting at 08:30. The number of places is limited, so it is recommended to arrive early in the morning. Here you can apply for temporary protection.
2
home

Find Housing

Look for temporary or permanent accommodation. You will need your own housing to complete the registration process.
3
how_to_reg

Register at the Commune

Go to your local commune to register your address, get Annex 15, and apply for the A card.
4
domain

Register at CPAS/OCMW

Visit your local CPAS/OCMW to apply for social assistance.
5
work

Register with Employment Office (Actiris/VDAB)

Register at Actiris or VDAB depending on your region to look for work or get jobseeker status.
6
volunteer_activism

Apply for Social Benefits

Once registered at the Commune and CPAS/OCMW, you can apply for social benefits if eligible.
7
school

Start Language Courses

Many regions offer free French or Dutch language courses for migrants.
link
